Government revised its estimate of the national government deficit to 3.2% 
of GDP in 2009.

Policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) is included with subprogram 
3.  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $1.15  million  equivalent.  ADB  will  provide

$350,000 in kind by providing counterpart staff and other facilities. 
 
This  is  the  second  of  three  TA  projects  for  public  financial  management 
envisaged  over  the  next  3 years.  The  three  projects  will  strengthen 
capacity  at  the  DBM  and  line  ministries  to  implement  public  financial 
management  reforms.  The  TA  will  support  the  DBM,  the  Bureau  of 
Treasury,  and  the  DOF  in  implementing  and  monitoring  key  public 
financial  management  reforms.  Component  1  will  support  the  DBM  and 
the  Bureau  of  Treasury  to  strengthen  cash  management  and  budget 
execution  procedures  and  processes.  It  will  support  the  rollout  of  the 
internal  control  systems  across  national  line  agencies.  Component  2  will 
support the interagency task force to develop a road map and action plan 
for integrating the government financial management information system. 
Component 3 will support capacity development at the new debt and risk 
management division at DOF, which will be responsible for drafting a debt 
management strategy and policies.  
 
A  team  of  international  and  national  consultants  will  implement  the  TA. 
ADB  will  engage  a  combination  of  a  consulting  firm  and  individuals  in 
accordance with Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from  time  to  time).  The  firm  will  be  engaged  following  quality-  and  cost-
based  selection  (80:20  quality–cost  ratio)  using  simplified  technical 
proposal.  A  total  of  51  person-months  of  consulting  services  will  be 
required (18 international and 33 national).

A. 

The Global Crisis 

2. 
The  proposed  DPSP  subprogram  3  comes  at  a  critical  time  for  the  Philippines.  It  is 
designed to maintain the momentum of its key development efforts at a time of global financial 
market failure and global recession. Like many other developing economies, the Philippines has 
had  to  cope  with  the  first-round  effects  of  the  turmoil  and  the  crisis  of  confidence  that  has 
disrupted  the  global  financial  system  and  limited  the  country's  access  to  commercial  debt 
markets  since  September  2008  (Appendix  4).  Coming  into  the  global  crisis,  the  Philippines’ 
macroeconomic  performance  was  sound.  The  economy  expanded  by  3.8%  in  2008—half  the 
7.3% in 2007, but above the regional average. The primary budget has been in surplus for the 
last 3 years and its overall deficit for 2008 was 0.9% of gross domestic product (GDP), low by 
international standards. The public debt–GDP ratio has continuously declined from over 80% in 
2003 to 56% by the end of 2008.   
 
3. 
The  Philippines  is  now  experiencing  the  second-round  effects  of  the  global  recession, 
which may be larger than those caused by the 1997–1998 Asian financial crisis. The economies 
of the Philippines’ major trading partners and recipients of Filipino workers have entered severe 
recessions. Global trade contracted by about 9% in the first quarter of 2009—the first time since 
1982. Consequently, Philippine exports (mainly influenced by the sharp contraction in exports of 
electronics) contracted by about 40% from December to April 2009 on a year-on-year basis. A 
consensus  in  the  international  community  is  that  the  global  economy  may  only  experience  a 
gradual  recovery  in  2010  and  this  turnaround  will  depend  critically  on  more  concerted  policy 
actions  to  stabilize  financial  conditions  and  bolster  demand  through  fiscal  expansion  and 
monetary policy. The Government has learned from the 1997–1998 financial crisis and its 2009 
budget  included  greater  discretionary  spending  mainly  on  infrastructure,  social  sectors,  and 
cash  transfers  to  the  poor.  As  a  result  of  these  spending  initiatives  and  lower  projected 
revenues, the 2009 budget deficit is projected to rise to 3.2% of GDP and the Government's net 
financing requirements will be about P270.6 billion. Despite policy makers' immediate focus on 
the  current  economic  crisis,  the  Government  also  considers  the  crisis  to  be  an  opportunity  to 
achieve  consensus  among  stakeholders  on  difficult  policy  issues  and  to  advance  its  medium-
term  development  objectives  in  fiscal  policy,  public  financial  management,  the  investment 
climate,  and  social  sectors,  recognizing  that  these  reforms  have  helped  the  Philippines  to 
weather this crisis and to position it for recovery.

6. 
To  help  implement  the  MTPDP  priorities,  the  Government  adopted  several  sector 
strategies,  most  with  a  time-bound  implementation  plan  and  clearly  defined  ministerial 
responsibilities;  some  are  supported  by  ADB  sector  programs  and  technical  assistance 
(Appendix 9). The fiscal consolidation strategy, which began in 2004, outlined the Government’s 
fiscal  stabilization  and  consolidation  strategy  up  to  2010.  It  was  successful  in  reducing  the 
national government budget deficit from 5.2% of gross domestic product (GDP) in 2003 to 0.2% 
in  2007  and  0.9%  in  2008.  Perhaps  one  of  the  most  important  achievements  of  the  fiscal 
consolidation  program  has  been  the  creation  of  fiscal  space  to  mitigate  some  of  the  poverty 
impacts  from  the  global  crisis  in  2009.  In  particular,  the  program  has  resulted  in  an  increased 
share of discretionary spending; from 26% of total budget expenditures in 2006 to 37% in 2008, 
with  the  social  sectors  and  infrastructure  the  main  beneficiaries  (Appendix  4).  As  a 
consequence  of  the  global  crisis  and  its  adverse  impact  on  the  Philippine  economy,  the 
Government relaxed its medium-term fiscal target for 2009 from a national government budget 
deficit  of  0.5%  of  GDP  to  3.2%  of  GDP  and  has  delayed  balancing  its  budget  until  2013.  The

ADB’s Country Strategy and Program, 2005–2007 for the Philippines identified three key 
priorities  for  ADB  assistance:  reducing  macroeconomic  instability  (through  fiscal  consolidation 
and  better  public  financial  management),  improving  the  investment  climate,  and  meeting  the 
needs  of  the  social  sectors. 5  The  DPSP  puts  this  strategy  into  operation  by  providing  an 
umbrella operation that complements and reinforces ADB’s sector program loans and projects. 
The DPSP, structured as a program cluster, aims to help the Government achieve its medium- 
to long-term goals of sustained economic growth of 6%–7% per annum, lower unemployment, 
and a reduction in poverty, as highlighted in the development policy letter addressed to the ADB 
President (Appendix 2). For effective development results, the DPSP focuses on a broad policy 
agenda  that  addresses  thematic  and  crosscutting  issues  in  four  core  areas:  (i)  fiscal 
sustainability; (ii) governance in public financial management and anticorruption initiatives in the 
key  revenue-raising  agencies,  (iii) the  investment  climate,  and  rural  development,  and  (iv) 
human capital and social inclusion. These are all key outcomes and outputs of the ADB Country 
Strategy and Program.

13. 
The  global  crisis  and  its  impact  on  the  Philippine  economy.  Like  many  other 
developing economies, the Philippines has had to cope with the first-round effects of the turmoil 
and a crisis of confidence that has disrupted the global financial system since September 2008. 
Philippine financial markets were significantly affected by capital flight in the second half of 2008 
and  the  global  credit  crunch  has  made  it  more  expensive  for  the  Philippine  public  and  private 
sectors  to  access  international  debt  markets  (Appendix  4).  However,  the  major  impact  on  the 
Philippine economy is the second-round effects of the collapse in global demand and its fiscal 
repercussions. The condition of the global economy deteriorated markedly in the fourth quarter 
of 2008 and new economic data on the global economy released in March 2009 confirm a much 
deeper,  broader  and  protracted  recession  in  several  of  the  Philippines’  major  trading  partners 
not seen since World War II.  The Philippine economy contracted by 2.3% in the first quarter of 
2009  on  a  quarter-on-quarter  basis  (adjusted  for  seasonal  effects),  as  external  demand  for 
exports plunged (Figure 1, b–d). Tourist arrivals have fallen heavily, dropping 15% at the end of 
December 2008 on a year-on-year basis. Remittances have held up much better than trade in 
goods and other services, but growth has virtually stalled with 2.9% growth in the first semester 
of  2009  compared  with  15%  growth  for  the  same  period  in  2008.  ADB  staff  estimate  that 
remittances  could  fall  by  2%–4%  in  the  second  half  of  2009,  based  on  the  experience  of  the 
1997–1998  Asian  financial  crisis  when  remittances  to  the  Philippines  from  overseas  Filipino 
workers residing in Singapore and Hong Kong declined by an average of 7% when these two 
economies experienced recessionary conditions. 
 
Against  this  background,  the  Government  has  revised  its  macroeconomic  framework

Repercussions  of  the  crisis  on  fiscal  policy. The global financial crisis has affected 
fiscal policy in three ways. First, the contraction in the economy means that it is necessary for 
the  Government  to  provide  a  modest  stimulus  in  2009,  while  maintaining  fiscal  discipline. 
Second, the contraction in the economy in the first quarter of 2009 has resulted in a decline in 
tax  collections.  As  a  result  of  the  increased  spending  and  projected  decline  in  revenues,  the 
Government  projects  the  deficit  to  rise  to  3.2%  of  GDP  in  2009.  Third,  tight  liquidity  in  global 
credit markets and elevated risks have raised the cost of financing the budget and refinancing 
public debt. While spreads have started to fall in recent months toward pre-crisis levels, global 
markets remain fragile and at the end of June 2009 spreads on Philippine international bonds 
increased again from an average spread of 270 bps in early June 2009 to 320 bps by the end of

16. 
Employment  losses  and  job  insecurity.  Until  mid-2008,  the  sustained  economic 
expansion was beginning to improve the Philippines' stubbornly high unemployment rate for the 
first time in a decade. Lower long-term economic growth coupled with relatively restrictive labor 
regulations meant longer-term unemployment in the Philippines was higher than in its regional 
neighbors. In 2007, the unemployment rate fell to an average of 7.3% from 7.9% in 2006. The 
latest data for April 2009 indicate an increase in the average unemployment rate to 7.6%. The 
Government is deeply concerned that the current global financial crisis will reverse its efforts to 
reduce  unemployment  and  therefore  poverty  and  that  it  will  lead  to  a  significant  reduction  in 
economic growth, retrenchments, domestic employment opportunities, and returns of overseas 
Filipino workers made redundant in recession-hit countries. Recent retrenchment data from the 
Department of Labor and Employment point to tens of thousands of layoffs, particularly in export 
industries  and  urban  centers.  An  ADB  household  survey  in  February  2009  reported  elevated 
feelings of job insecurity among workers with 20% of employed workers feeling they may not be 
in their current job within the next 12 months, of which one-fifth of these workers (or 4% of total 
workers surveyed) expect to lose their jobs because of the performance of the economy (Figure 
2).17 Sixty percent of employed workers expect it to be more difficult to find a new or better job in 
2009 than in 2008. The initial impact of job and income losses will probably occur in the major 
urban  industrial  centers  and  among  the  nonpoor  and  near-poor  since  wage  workers  are 
concentrated among these groups of households. However, multiplier effects and a potential fall 
in remittances mean the impacts of the crisis will be broader and the incidence of poverty and its 
severity will rise.

18. 
Fiscal  program.  In  mid-2008,  the  Government  decided,  and  its  development  partners 
concurred,  that  the  balanced  budget  target  date  should  be  pushed  back  to  2010  to  provide 
flexibility  in  fiscal  policy  in  2008  and  2009  for  programs  to  mitigate  the  impact  of  increases  in 
food prices on the poor and to maintain priority spending programs if the economy slowed down. 
The Government targeted a deficit of no more  than 1% of GDP in 2008, 0.5% in 2009, and a 
balanced  budget  in  2010.  However,  with  the  severe  contraction  in  global  demand  since 
September  2008  and  the  recognition  by  the  Government  and  its  development  partners  that  a 
larger fiscal expansion is needed, the Government has revised its medium-term fiscal program. 
It  plans  an  increase  in  the  national government  budget  deficit  to  3.2% of  GDP  in  2009,  2%  in 
2010, and a balanced budget by 2013. The 2009 national government budget deficit translates 
to  an  actual  fiscal  expansion  of  up  to  2.3%  of  GDP  over  2008  levels, 18  low  by  regional 
standards.19 It covers less than one-half of the expected negative output gap in 2009 (i.e., the 
gap between potential and actual economic growth, Figure 3). In the current global environment, 
the Government faces challenges to its fiscal program in both the short and medium terms. In 
the  short  term,  the  Government  needs  to  ensure  that  its  fiscal  expansion  in  2009  provides  an 
effective  stimulus  to  the  economy.  This  will  mean  ensuring  that  the  stimulus  is  timely,  well 
targeted, temporary, and transparent. In this regard, a key challenge will be to maintain critical 
public  spending  and  to  speed  up  disbursements  for  infrastructure  spending  in  the  key 
procurement  agencies.  Measures  should  focus  on  lifting  the  relatively  low  absorptive  capacity 
rates  of  key  spending  agencies,  better  cash  management,  advancing  the  infrastructure 
procurement  process,  and  scaling  up  targeted  social  assistance  and  employment  programs. 
With tax collections falling in the first quarter of 2009, the added challenge for the Government 
will  be  to  ensure  predictability  in  its  gross  financing  needs  for  2009.  In  the  medium  term,  the 
Government  needs  to  ensure  it  sustains  revenue  sustainability  to  fund  priority  programs  and 
longer-term  debt  sustainability.  The  crisis  also  provides  an  opportunity  for  the  Government  to 
revisit its balanced budget objective and to explore the feasibility of alternative fiscal rules that 
could anchor fiscal policy (Appendix 4).

Tax  revenue  performance.  Tax  collection  (cash  collections  from  the  BIR  and  BOC) 
grew by 11.0% in 2008 over 2007 levels. BIR cash collection was up 9.0% in 2008, short of its 
target of 13.5% as collections in the fourth quarter significantly slowed and actually declined in 
December  (Figure  4).  Substantial  improvements  in  collections  were  made  in  some  taxes: 
corporate income tax collection increased by 18.3% over 2007 levels and excise tax collections 
on  tobacco  products  were  also  better  by  18.8%.  Value-added  collections  under  the  BIR's 
jurisdiction fell by 3.2% over 2007 levels. Poor compliance with value-added tax (VAT) appears 
to occur in the services sector, especially in retail and trade, which comprise a large number of 
smaller taxpayers. Continued weak tax administration and inefficiencies in the tax policy indicate 
that the BIR has been unable to lift VAT collections through improvements in tax efficiency and 
enforcement.  The  prevalence  of  VAT  exemptions  (resulting  in  breaks  in  the  VAT  chain  and 
thereby  weaker  self-compliance),  and  generous  taxable  income  deductions  in  the  growth 
sectors of the economy continue to limit growth-induced tax collection. In the first semester of 
2009, tax collection fell by 5.2% over levels in the same period in 2008, reflecting the economic 
contraction in the Philippines. Customs collections fell 8.3% (VAT on imported goods fell 12.9%) 
and the BIR's collections fell by 5.1% on a year-on-year basis. ADB assessments indicate that 
tax  revenues  in  the  Philippines  have  historically  exhibited  a  systematic,  moderate  procyclical 
pattern,  i.e.,  during  periods  of  fast  economic  growth  direct  and  indirect  taxes  grow  faster  than 
nominal GDP, and during sharp slowdowns, taxes fall faster than nominal GDP. ADB estimates 
that,  based  on  a  low-growth  scenario  for  2009  and  2010,  the  tax  to  GDP  ratio  will  decline  for 
2009 and some of the decline will carry over into 2010 (Appendix 4).

Debt  management.  Improvements  made  in  public  debt  management  since  2005 have 
resulted  in  significant  fiscal  savings.  Overall,  debt  interest  costs  in  the  national  government 
budget have fallen from 36.7% of total national government revenues in 2005 to 22.6% in 2008,

Affairs  (covering  contingent  liabilities  of  government-owned  and  controlled  corporations  and 
others),  and  the  International  Finance  Group  (covering  official  development  assistance  and 
international  commercial  borrowings).  Monitoring  of  contingent  liabilities  under  the  Build–
operate–transfer law is done through the National Economic and Development Authority (NEDA) 
investment  coordination  committee  (ICC).  Consequently,  debt  management  is  not  conducted 
within an integrated debt framework as suggested by best international practice. A medium-term 
debt management and risk strategy and policies are needed.

continues  to  be  made.  The  DBM  continues  to  increase  the  use  of  the  MTEF  in  preparing  the

undertaken  a  study  of  government  financial  information  systems  and  has  begun  consultations

development  of  the  GFMIS  over  the  medium  term  will  be  important  to  enhance  the  efficiency

49. 
Fiscal  discipline. The Government’s immediate objectives are to protect critical public 
spending within a disciplined fiscal framework and to reduce nonfinancial public sector debt to 
65% of GDP by 2010. In 2008, (i) the national government deficit came in at 0.9% of GDP, the 
third  consecutive  year  it  has  been  below  1%,  and  a  consolidated  public  sector  surplus 
surpassed program expectations; and (ii) nonfinancial sector public debt fell from 87% of GDP 
in 2005 to 60% in 2008, and is on track to return to debt levels of the early 1990s. The national 
government debt decreased from 72% in 2005 to 56% by the end of 2008. 
 
50. 
Tax revenue sustainability. Tax revenues increased by 11% in 2008. Major gains were 
achieved  in corporate  income  tax  collection  (18%)  and  tobacco  excise  (19%).  VAT  collections 
fell  by  3%  in  2008  due  to  weak  compliance  in  the  services  sector.  During  subprogram  3  the 
Government  initiated  medium-term  actions  to  improve  revenue  sustainability,  including  
raising  the  excise  tax  rate  in  January  2009  in  line  with  existing  legislation.  The  DOF  has 
submitted a bill to Congress to reform excise taxes, including indexing specific rates to inflation 
and  reducing  the  number  of  tax  bands  to  two.  While  tax  administration  reforms  were  slow  to 
begin,  some  progress  has  been  made:  (i)  the  BIR,  with  assistance  from  USAID  and  the 
Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC), computerized 71 revenue district offices (97% of the 
uncomputerized  offices)  so  that  tax  information  can  be  provided  online  to  the  central  office  in 
Manila;  (ii)  the  backlog  of  tax  registrations  and  returns  has  been  reduced,  with  348,465  tax 
registrations  and  1,235,889  income  tax  returns  encoded  and  filed  with  assistance  from  the 
USAID  and  MCC  grant;  and  (iii)  some  progress  was  made  in  validating  about  47%  of  the 
unregistered corporations (about 9,429 registered at the Securities and Exchange Commission) 
and inactive taxpayers in the database (162,352 taxpayers) identified under subprogram 2. The 
revenue district offices are continuing to validate the identified taxpayers.

will build on activities under the second TA project, including the integrated GFMIS, the rollout of 
internal  control  systems,  debt  management,  and  cash  revenue  forecasting.  The  second  TA 
project  is  estimated  to  cost  $1,150,000  equivalent,  of  which  ADB  will  provide  $800,000,  to  be 
financed  by  the  ADB’s  TA  funding  program  (TASF—other  sources).  The  Government  will 
provide the remaining $350,000 in kind by providing counterpart staff and other facilities. A team

of 2011. The TA purpose, outputs, methodology, implementation arrangements, and budget are

DEVELOPMENT POLICY LETTER AND POLICY MATRIX 
 

 
Our  macroeconomic  policy  response  to  the  external  shocks  has  been  both  appropriate  and 
responsive. Earlier in 2008, the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) shifted to a tighter monetary 
position to counter possible second round inflationary effects from the commodity price surge. 
Then in the fourth quarter it shifted to an expansionary position to ensure sufficient liquidity in 
the banking system against rapidly falling inflation. By May 2009 inflation had fallen to 3.3% well 
within  the  BPS's  inflation  target  for  2009.  To  boost  confidence  in  the  financial  sector,  the 
Government  took  a  number  of  preemptive  measures  aimed  at  increasing  liquidity  in  the 
domestic bank system, assuring confidence of depositors, and strengthening the central bank's 
lender of last resort facility.  
 
With  these  preemptive  measures  in  place,  the  macroeconomy  stabilized  and  key  indicators 
showed encouraging signs of improvement. Commercial bank lending continued robust growth 
at about 20% in the first quarter of 2009 on a year-on-year basis; the stock market and the peso 
have stabilized since November and yields on domestic bonds have recently fallen back to pre-
crisis  levels,  Gross  international  reserves  continued  to  accumulate  in  2009,  equivalent  to  6.3 
months of import cover and three times greater than external debt maturing this year, providing 
a  sufficient  buffer  against  further  moderate  external  shocks.  Spreads  on  Philippine  sovereign 
dollar bonds have also declined in recent months but still remain above pre-crisis levels.  
 
The global crisis has impacted on our fiscal situation, although this remains manageable as a 
result  of  successful  implementation  of  our  fiscal  consolidation  strategy  since  2004.  Our  fiscal 
consolidation efforts brought down the non-financial sector public debt from over 100% of GDP 
in 2003 to 61 % at the end of 2008 back to levels last seen in the early 1990s. Perhaps one of 
the  most  important  achievements  of  the  fiscal consolidation  program  has  been  the  creation  of 
fiscal space to mitigate some of the poverty impacts from the global crisis in 2009. In particular, 
the  program  has  resulted  in  an  increased  share  of  discretionary  spending  from  26  %  of  total 
budget expenditures in 2006 to 37 % in 2008, with the social sectors and infrastructure the main 
beneficiaries. 
 
With  these  challenging  times,  and  our  lessons  learned  from  the  1998  crisis  and  its 
repercussions for fiscal sustainability, we are committed to maintain fiscal discipline necessary 
to maintain investor confidence in the economy, while at the same time creating fiscal space to 
protect  spending  in  the  social  sectors  and  provide  an  effective  and  timely  stimulus  to  the 
economy. Therefore, we are targeting a budget deficit of 3.2% of GDP in 2009, lower than our 
regional neighbors. The budget provides for an increase in discretionary spending as part of our 
countercyclical  stimulus.  Key  initiatives  include  the  scaling  up  of  the  conditional  cash  transfer 
program (CCT) to 337,234 households in 2008 and 2009 and we intend to scale it up further. 
We have also begun implementing the Comprehensive Livelihood and Emergency Employment 
Program (CLEEP) with a target of creating 373,117 jobs. As of June 2009, 137,000 jobs have 
been created under the program. As part of our stimulus we have advanced procurement and 
spending  on  infrastructure  projects.  Key  procurement  agencies  such  as  Department  of 
Agriculture,  Department  of  Education,  Department  of  Pubic  Works  and  Highways,  and  the 
Department of Transport and Communication have committed themselves to front loading their 
spending programs in the first semester to 60% of the total 2009 program. Our data suggests 
that these commitments have been broadly achieved. We are committed to fiscal sustainability 
and have announced a revised fiscal program up to 2013. We are targeting a budget deficit of 
2%  in  2010  and  a  balanced  budget  by  2013.  This  will  be  achieved  by  cutting  back  on  crisis-
related discretionary spendiising the revenue to GDP ratio by one percentage point.

1. 
The  sector  analysis  assesses  recent  macroeconomic  developments  and  identifies  the 
issues  and  threats  faced  by  the  Government  in  achieving  its  medium-term  development 
objectives  of  fiscal  sustainability,  macroeconomic  performance,  and  poverty  reduction.  The 
immediate  pressing  issues  for  macroeconomic policy  are  the  deceleration  in  economic  growth 
and  its  fiscal  repercussions.  The  critical  issues  for  the  Government  in  the  short  term  are  to 
sustain  critical  public  spending  and  to  address  additional  financing  needs  arising  from  the 
decline  in  tax  revenues  in  the  first  quarter  of  2009.  Over  the  medium  term,  the  Government 
priorities  include  sustaining  priority  spending  by  raising  revenues,  improving  the  efficiency  of 
public  expenditure  management,  and  increasing  the  effectiveness  of  debt  management.  The 
Government  has  outlined  a  revised  fiscal  sustainability  strategy  with  medium-term  balanced 
budget targets. While the balanced budget target has served the Philippines well over the last 4 
years, the current crisis has provided an opportunity to revisit the policy of balancing the budget 
target  and  explore  alternative  fiscal  rules  that  could  anchor  fiscal  policy  and  operations  in  the 
future.   
 
A.  
 
Economic growth was 4.6% in 2008, lower than the 7.3% in 2007, but above the regional 
2. 
average. The slower economic growth was a combination of a contraction in public spending in 
the first quarter of 2008, a surge in domestic inflation that reduced domestic consumption from 
6%  in  2007  to  4.6%  in  2008,  and  the  recession  in  the  United  States  that  lowered  demand  for 
Philippines  exports.  Private  investment  continued  to  expand  in  the  first  half  of  2008,  with 
purchases of durable equipment expanding by 6% on a year-on-year basis, among the highest 
rates for a decade, and private construction expanding by 20% for 2008. As the global crisis has 
intensified since September 2008 and global demand has contracted, investment and trade has

Fiscal Policy 

1. 

Fiscal Crisis and Consolidation 

5. 
Fiscal  consolidation  from  2004  to  2007.  Fiscal  indiscipline,  coupled  with  poor 
monetary  policy  management  until  1993  when  the  central  bank  was  reformed,  were  the  main 
contributors to macroeconomic instability from the late 1970s to 2004. In 2005, the Philippines 
emerged from a period of serious fiscal difficulty. From 1998 to 2004, budget revenues dropped, 
which significantly suppressed expenditure in the social sectors, leading to a substantial decline 
in public sector real wages.1 The deficit reached 5.2% of GDP and the nonfinance public sector 
debt  exceeded  100%  of  GDP  in  2004.  The  high  and  unsustainable  deficits  triggered  bouts  of 
peso  exchange  rate  instability.  The  Government  has  restored  macroeconomic  stability  and 
maintained  it  through  fiscal  discipline.  The  cornerstone  and  the  measure  with  the  highest 
revenue  impact  was  the  reform  of  value-added  tax  in  November  2005,  which  extended  the 
value-added  tax  base  to  energy  products,  and  increased  the  rate  from  10%  to  12%  effective 
February  2006.  Other  measures  included  increasing  (i)  excise  taxes  on  alcohol  and  tobacco 
products  by  30%  at  the  end  of  2004  (increased  again  in  January  2007  and  January  2009, 
although  not  fully  indexed  to  inflation),  (ii)  the  corporate  income  tax  rate  from  32%  to  35% 
(which reverted to 30% in January 2009 as mandated in the amendments to tax legislation), and 
(iii)  electricity  tariffs.  As  a  consequence  of  these  reforms,  tax  revenues  grew  by  over  1.3 
percentage  points  of  GDP  in  2006,  the  national  government  deficit  fell  to  0.9%  of  GDP  from 
2.7% in 2005, and the consolidated public sector budget turned in a surplus for the first time in 
almost a decade, aided by the improvement in the finances of the National Power Corporation. 
Fiscal  consolidation  continued  in  2007  with  the  national  government  deficit  falling  to  0.2%  of 
GDP and the consolidated public sector budget remaining in surplus for a second consecutive 
year.  
 
6. 
Increased social expenditures. The fiscal crisis and subsequent consolidation program 
suppressed  expenditures  in  the  social  sectors  and  in  infrastructure.  However,  by  2006 
substantial resources were freed for priority spending in the 2007–2009 budgets. In particular, 
discretionary  spending  in  the  national  government  budget  increased  from  26%  of  total 
expenditures  in  2006  to  37%  in  2008  with  the  social  sectors  and  infrastructure  the  main 
beneficiaries  (Figure  A4.3).  The  Government  has  provided  substantial  real  increases  in  social 
spending with the Department of Health (DOH) budget doubled in 2009 compared with its 2006 
levels;  the  Department  of  Education  (DepEd)  budget  up  by  42%  in  real  terms  over  the  same 
period; and the Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD) budget up by 300% in 
real terms over the same period.

Global Financial Crisis and Fiscal Expansion 

7. 
Fiscal  policy  behavior  over  the  economic  cycle.  In  the  past,  fiscal  policy  in  the 
Philippines has not been effective in mitigating the effects of economic downturns. This is partly 
a characteristic of most developing economies, as fiscal policy usually does not have embedded 
in it automatic stabilizers on the expenditure side of the national government budget that would 
allow  for  effective  countercyclical  spending.  In  the  Philippines,  relatively  high  public  debt  and 
large nondiscretionary commitments (interest payments and transfers to local government units) 
in  the  budget  limited  the  opportunity  for  discretionary  countercyclical  spending.  The  fiscal 
consolidation program that has been in carried out since 2004 suppressed primary expenditures. 
The  national  government  budget  does  have  modest  automatic  stabilizers  on  the  revenue  side 
but these are generally offset by the expenditure side so that the overall national primary budget 
balance appears to be generally neutral to economic downturns. Figure A4.4 presents trends in 
the Philippines' fiscal policy behavior over the economic cycle (as measured by the output gap). 
It shows the percentage point changes in tax revenues to GDP since 1991 mapped against the 
economic cycle. As is apparent from the figures, tax revenues tend to be moderately procyclical, 
i.e., tax collections grow more quickly than nominal GDP during higher growth periods (implying 
an increase in the tax ratio) and drop more quickly than nominal GDP during economic troughs 
(implying a fall in the tax ratio). Indirect taxes (excluding customs duties) levied on goods and 
services  and  direct  income  taxes  generally  move  together  over  the  economic  cycle,  although 
changes  in  direct  income  taxes  tend  to  carry  over  into  the  next  year  as  the  tax  code  permits 
corporations to carry over losses to the succeeding fiscal year. The large drop in tax collections 
in the first 4 months of 2009 is consistent with this cyclical pattern. Tax (cash) collections from 
the  Bureau  of  Internal  Revenue  (BIR)  fell  6.5%  on  a  year-on-year  basis.2 Customs  collection 
(duties and VAT on imported goods) from the Bureau of Customs (BOC) fell 12% for the same 4 
months  on  a  year-on-year  basis  as  imports  plummeted.  The  13%  drop  in  VAT  collection  on 
imported  goods  was  the  major  contributor  to  the  fall  in  customs  revenue  during  this  period.

3. 

Medium-Term Fiscal Policy Issues 

 
9. 
Considerable  fiscal  gains  have  been  achieved  since  2005,  and  fiscal  space  has  been 
provided from increased tax revenues. Building on these is an important medium-term goal. In 
the context of the current crisis and the Government's medium-term budget framework, the four 
major  medium-term  issues  are:  (i)  exploring  alternative  fiscal  rules  to  balance  the  budget, 
(ii)  sustaining  priority  spending  by  increasing  revenues,  (iii)  improving  the  efficiency  of  public 
expenditure management, and (iv) better debt management practices. 
 
10. 
Alternative  fiscal  rules.  While  the  Government's  fiscal  policy  and  its  medium-term 
target of a balanced budget has served the Philippines very well in achieving consolidation, the 
global crisis has provided an opportunity to explore with stakeholders alternative fiscal rules. As 
discussed in paras. 8–9, in the past fiscal policy has not been effective in mitigating the effects 
of the economic cycle. In fact budget expenditures have at times exhibited a procyclical pattern. 
Moreover,  because  of  external  shocks  to  the  economy,  the  balanced  budget  target  has  been 
changed three times since 2005, potentially undermining its credibility. An increasing number of 
countries  have  adopted  fiscal  rules  to  anchor  fiscal  policy  and  these  rules  are  generally 
formalized  through  legislation  such  as  fiscal  responsibility  acts.  Rules  may  pertain  to  debt, 
budget balances (overall or primary), expenditures, or some combination of these.3 For example, 
Thailand does not set budget ceilings but anchors fiscal policy in debt rules set in legislation and 
Ministry  of  Finance  policy  guidelines  for  public  debt.  It  may  also  be  feasible  to  anchor  fiscal 
policy to public debt rules in the Philippines. The post-program monitoring framework includes a 
measure to assess fiscal policy and explores the feasibility of formalizing fiscal rules.  
 
Sustaining  priority  spending. The Government’s goal is to raise national government 
11. 
noninterest  expenditures  by  an  additional  1  percentage  point  of  GDP  over  the  next  2  years 
(excluding countercyclical spending in 2009). To achieve this goal, the Government targets an 
increase  in  tax  revenues  to  15%.  The  tax  revenue  target  is  achievable  over  the  medium  term 
but  requires  greater  efforts.  Revenue  management  is  challenged  by  (i)  the  proliferation  of  tax 
incentives in growth sectors of the economy that may have resulted in as much as P47 billion in 
foregone  revenues;  (ii)  generous  income  tax  deductions  that  have  eroded  the  tax  base;  (iii)  a 
poorly  structured  excise  tax  regime;  and  (iv)  weak  tax  administration,  including  administering 
value added tax and modernizing business procedures and systems of revenue district offices 
(RDOs).  The  Government  is  systematically  addressing  these  issues.  The  Bureau  of  Internal 
Revenue  (BIR)  has  a  comprehensive  tax  administration  reform  program  to  2010  with  support 
from  the  World  Bank,  Swedish  International  Development  Agency,  and  ADB  (in  2008),  but 
implementation  has  been  slower  than  expected.  This  is  partly  due  to  the  complexity  of  the 
reform  program  and  its  outreach  to  all  RDOs,  but  it  is  also  because  the  BIR  lacks  resources. 
Nevertheless,  progress  has  been  made.  The  Government  has  allocated  an  additional  P1.0 
billion to its personnel budget and this could potentially increase staffing by 25%. Ninety-seven 
percent  of  all  uncomputerized  RDOs  have  now  been  computerized  and  the  backlog  of  tax 
registrations and returns has been reduced, with over 350,000 tax registrations and 1.2 million 
in income return files encoded into the electronic system. The Government has also submitted 
draft bills to Congress on amending excise tax legislation (submitted in 2008) and consolidating 
investment  incentives  (submitted  at  the  end  of  2007)  to  improve  revenue  sustainability.    Over 
the longer term, the Government will need to continue to address budget resource allocations to 
the  BIR  as  it  implements  its  tax  reforms  and  enhances  tax  administration  in  monitoring  tax 
credits, managing tax arrears, tax audits, and anticorruption programs. Tax exemptions initiated 
by Congress have eroded the tax base in recent years.

Employment  scheduled  for  later  in  2009.  However,  during  the  Development  Policy  Support 
Program  (DPSP),  the  Government,  ADB,  and  other  development  partners  have  identified

Debt  sustainability.  The  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  undertook  an  Article  IV 
Consultation with the Philippines in November 2008 (footnote 2). As part of its consultations, the 
IMF  undertook  a  debt  sustainability  assessment  (DSA)  based  on  different  economic  growth, 
interest rate, primary budget balance, and exchange rate shocks. The IMF updated its DSA for 
the purposes of the DPSP 3. This appendix summarizes the pertinent findings of the DSA. 
 
14. 
The  Philippines'  public  sector  debt  is  broadly  sustainable,  but  short-term  risks  have 
increased due to global financial instability. Public debt as a share of GDP has declined to ratios 
last  seen  in  the  early  1990s,  but  remains  high  by  regional  standards.  At  the  end  of  2008, 
national government public debt amounted to 56% of GDP, down from its peak of 83% in 2003 
(Figure A3). Nonfinancial public sector (NFPS) debt declined to 59.9% from 101.0% during the 
same  period  (Figure  A3).  A  prudent  borrowing  strategy,  including  lengthening  the  average 
maturity  of  debt  to  7.1  years  and  moving  to  domestic  financing;4  fiscal  discipline  (operating 
primary  budget  surpluses);  and  sustained  economic  growth  contributed  to  the  rapid  decline. 
Debt  servicing  costs  as  a  share  of  national  government  budget  revenues  also  declined  from 
36.7% in 2005 to 22.6% in 2007, thereby freeing up substantial resources for priority spending 
since 2007. However, at 8% of GDP, the Philippines’ public debt servicing costs (amortization 
and interest payments) are high by regional standards.

A.    Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in the Philippines: The Development Policy Support Program 
(DPSP)  policy  areas  largely  correspond  with  those  of  the  Government  as  spelled  out  in  the  Medium-Term  Philippine 
Development Plan (MTPDP) 2004–2010, which focuses on five core areas: (i) economic growth and job creation; (ii) energy 
dependency  and  power  sector  reforms;  (iii)  social  justice  and  basic  needs;  (iv)  education  and  youth  opportunities;  and 
(v) anticorruption measures and governance. The MTPDP mission is to “fight poverty by building prosperity for the greatest 
number of Filipino people.”  
 
The  focus  of  ADB's  Country  Strategy  and  Program  (CSP)  and  the  country  operations  business  plan  (COBP)  for  the 
Philippines  is  on  fiscal  consolidation,  an  improved  investment  climate,  and  accelerated    progress  toward  the  Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs), as confirmed by the country assistance program evaluation (CAPE) for the Philippines and an 
ADB  study  on  the  critical  development  constraints  in  the  country.  The  Government  has  made  substantial  progress  in 
addressing  fiscal  consolidation.    This  is  necessary  to  increase  social  expenditures.  However,  the  global  financial  crisis  and 
second-round external demand destruction has hurt the Philippines and has had fiscal repercussions. Pressures on the fiscal 
situation are exerted from two sources. On the one hand, there are increased public demands for additional social spending to 
mitigate the impact of the crisis on poverty. On the other, there was a decline in budget revenues in the first semester of 2009. 
The  challenge  faced  by  the  Government  is  to  protect  recent  gains  in  social  expenditures  while  also  providing  additional 
assistance through its social programs such as the CCT program; carrying out a fiscal stimulus through increase infrastructure 
spending;  and  ensuring  medium-term  debt  sustainability.  Consequently,  the  national  government  budget  deficit  will  rise  to 
3.2%  of  GDP  in  2009  and  2%  in  2010.  The  DPSP  will  contribute  to  measures  to  protect  critical  public  spending  and  at  the 
same time will ensure ensures fiscal discipline.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
1.  Key Issues  
The  deceleration  in  the  Philippine  economy  threatens  to  reverse  recent  gains  in  reducing  unemployment,  which  has  been 
steadily declining in the last 2 years. Most recently, it has increased from 7.3% in 2008 to 7.6% in 2009. Other indicators point 
to the adverse effects of the crisis on the labor market. Economic growth in 2009 is estimated in the range of 0.8%–1.8%, this 
translates to a decline in per capita incomes of –1.7% to –0.7%. This would result in an increase in the incidence of poverty. If 
remittances  fall  this  would  also  increase  poverty.  To  mitigate  the  impacts  of  the  crisis,  the  Government  has  piloted  the 
conditional cash transfer (CCT) program to 337,345 families in 2008 and 2009. This is likely to cushion the impact on poverty 
in the same way as Indonesia's unconditional cash transfer scheme.  
 
2. Design Features. With support through the DPSP, the Government is addressing these issues of poverty and vulnerability 
to poverty by reforming social protection programs, scaling up the CCT program, increasing spending on the social sectors, 
infrastructure,  and  labor-intensive  public  employment  programs  (such  as  the  Comprehensive  Livelihood  and  Emergency 
Employment Program). 
 
C.  Poverty Impact Analysis for Policy-Based Lending  
The DPSP supports the Government to address these issues through the program’s public financial management and social 
sector  components.  Under  subprogram  3,  additional  policy  triggers  were  introduced  specifically  to  mitigate  the  poverty 
impacts  of  the  current  global  crisis.  The  DPSP  supports  increased  spending  on  the  social  sectors  in  areas  where  the 
Philippines  is  lagging  in  progress  toward  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs),  for  example  in  education.  It  also 
supports the piloting and scaling up of the CCT program, which links assistance with outcomes in family education and health. 
The DPSP also supports the public employment program; and the speeding up of disbursements of critical public spending 
and advancing procurement process through Department of Budget and Management crisis-related initiatives.

Findings of Social Analysis  
ADB  assessments  suggest  that  the  possible  decline  in  per  capita  incomes  in  2009  and  increased  unemployment  will

domestic recovery is weak, poverty and unemployment effects will manifest themselves over a longer period. The magnitude 
of  the  recovery  and  growth  of  remittances  from  overseas  Filipino  workers  will  be  critical.  As  of  June  of  2009,  remittances 
remain  flat  and  are  expected  to  decline  in  the  range  of  2%–4%  in  second  semester  of  2009.  However,  a  disconcerting 
prospect is a  possible substantial  downward revision in the global economic outlook for 2009–2010,  which  would  affect the 
prospects for exports and remittances.
